Courtesy of the Bad Astronomer, here's an impressive and detailed visualization of the progressively explored and terraformed Mars. Pretty neat, coming from a music video.

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/WjNssEVlB6M?start=20&feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

Very cool video. Very bad music lol. Sadly terraforming Mars will never be viable. By time we have the technology to do what you see in that video we will have much better options for a new place to live. Mars has little to no magnetic field. There'd nothing we can do about that even WITH that technology. We'd need to build a massive dynomo otherwise any attempt to thicken the atmosphere gets blown away by the sun. 

Now I said terraforming won't be viable. You'll never be able to stand on the surface without a breather in shorts and a tshirt. But living on Mars in biodomes/under ground I can see. We eventually won't have a choice. Once our sun starts to heat up and cook the Earth we have to find a new home. So as the goldilocks zone of our system gets pushed back we will follow it. Assuming we haven't figured out interstellar travel by then. In which case were screwed.

Mars is not a solution, in the case of our sun turning into a gas giant, mars would be a band aid to fix an aortic aneurism.
If our sun turned into a gas giant all the planets and asteroids (except possible some very eccentric-orbiting rocks at their apoapsis) would be flung out of the system.
Is impossible to take this video seriosly with that "music", in fact it makes the video unwatchable.
... Why would the sun turn into a gas giant? Who said that?
I agree with AngelLestat. It's a shame, really.

Probably meant to say red giant...

Besides - in about 10 000 of years we went from cave dwellings and hunter-gatherer lifestyle to nuclear power and space exploration - who can say what we'll have at our disposal 10 000 years from now?
